resp: C# is a modern, object-oriented programming language developed by Microsoft. It's used for building Windows apps, games with Unity, web services, and more.
Main C# data types: int (numbers), string (text), bool (true/false), double/float (decimals), char (single character), and var (inferred type).
Declare variables in C# like: int age = 25; string name = "John"; bool isActive = true; Use var for type inference: var count = 10;
C# strings: Use double quotes "text". Common methods: Length, ToUpper(), ToLower(), Contains(), Substring(). String interpolation: $"Hello {name}"
C# arrays: int[] numbers = new int[5]; or int[] nums = {1,2,3,4,5}; Access with index: nums[0]. Property: Length.
C# Lists are dynamic arrays: List<int> numbers = new List<int>(); Methods: Add(), Remove(), Count, Contains(), Clear().
C# Dictionary stores key-value pairs: Dictionary<string, int> ages = new Dictionary<string, int>(); Use: Add(key, value), ContainsKey(), Remove().
C# if statements: if (condition) { code } else if (condition) { code } else { code }. Use &&(and), ||(or), !(not) for logic.
C# switch: switch(variable) { case value1: code; break; case value2: code; break; default: code; break; }
C# for loop: for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) { code }. Initialize counter, set condition, define increment.
C# foreach: foreach (var item in collection) { code }. Iterates through all items in arrays, lists, or collections.
C# methods: returnType MethodName(parameters) { code; return value; }. Example: int Add(int a, int b) { return a + b; }
C# classes are blueprints: class Person { public string Name; public int Age; public void Speak() { } }. Create with: Person p = new Person();
C# inheritance: class Dog : Animal { }. Dog inherits from Animal. Use 'base' to call parent methods. Use 'virtual' and 'override' for polymorphism.
C# interfaces define contracts: interface IDrawable { void Draw(); }. Classes implement: class Circle : IDrawable { public void Draw() { } }
C# LINQ queries collections: var result = list.Where(x => x > 5).OrderBy(x => x).Select(x => x * 2); Needs using System.Linq;
C# lambda expressions: (parameters) => expression. Example: numbers.Where(x => x > 5) or Func<int, int> square = x => x * x;
C# async/await: async Task<int> GetDataAsync() { await Task.Delay(1000); return 42; } Call with: int result = await GetDataAsync();
C# delegates are function pointers: delegate int Operation(int x, int y); Operation op = Add; int result = op(5, 3);
